div.class: sp column one border-box hp-region-c-sp-col-1 noprint

a.span: Protocol for Secondary Students Not Currently Participating in Intersholastic Athletics
When to Keep a Child Home...

strong.em: **NOTE: The following information on the coronavirus is from the NYS Department of Health and NYS Education Department, with updates provided by the Grand Island Central School District.

span.p: A new coronavirus called 2019 Novel (new) Coronavirus (COVID-19) was first found in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China. This virus had not been found in humans before. This coronavirus can lead to fever, cough and trouble breathing or shortness of breath. There are currently thousands of newly diagnosed cases every day across the globe, including in the United States.

span.em: Please click through the following sections for more info:

div.p: Since this virus is very new, health authorities continue to carefully watch how this virus spreads. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) is working hard to learn as much as possible about this new virus, so that we can better understand how it spreads and causes illness. The CDC considers this virus to be a serious public health concern. You can view updated travel information related to COVID-19.
Health experts believe the virus probably spreads from animals to humans and from person to person. It’s not clear yet how easily the virus spreads from person-to-person.

There are currently no vaccines available to protect against this virus. The New York State Department of Health (DOH) recommends the following ways to minimize the spread of all respiratory viruses, including COVID-19:

ul.li: Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. Use an alcoholbased hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol if soap and water are not available.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands.
Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
Stay home when you are sick.
Cover your mouth and nose with a tissue or your sleeve (not your hands) when coughing or sneezing. If you use a tissue, throw it in the trash.
Routinely clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces.
CDC recommends that travelers avoid all travel to China.

div.p: Information to date suggests that COVID-19 causes mild-to-moderate illness and symptoms like the flu, including fever, cough, and difficulty breathing.

h1.aria-label: Are visitors from China being screened?
h1.span: Are visitors from China being screened?

div.p: Yes, as of February 2nd new screening protocols are conducted for individuals entering the US from China at designated airports.

PreK-12 schools may have students who attend school and have traveled to various areas in Asia, including China. Students should not be excluded from school or any school activities based on race, country of origin, or recent travel (or a family member’s recent travel), including to any part of China. Schools may only exclude a student if a local health department informs the school that a student must comply with a quarantine order or the student is symptomatic of a communicable or infectious disease pursuant to Education Law §906.

h1.aria-label: Important Health Info for Those Who Recently Traveled and Experience Symptoms
h1.span: Important Health Info for Those Who Recently Traveled and Experience Symptoms

div.p: If you recently traveled and feel sick with fever, cough or trouble breathing; OR you develop symptoms within 14 days of traveling, you should:

ul.li: Seek medical care right away. Call ahead and tell them about your travel and symptoms.
Stay home, except for seeking medical care.
Cover your mouth and nose with a tissue or your sleeve (not your hands) when coughing or sneezing.
Wash hands often with soap and warm water for at least 20 seconds. If soap and water are not available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol.

div.p: This is an emerging, rapidly changing situation. For questions please contact your local department of health or the NYS DOH Novel Coronavirus hotline at 1-888-364-3065.
We encourage you to keep up to date about COVID-19, its treatment and prevention by visiting the following websites:

li.a: NYSDOH directory of local health departments
New York State Center for School Health website
